Myth1: \n Soothe a burn by applying butter
Myth2: \n apply an ice pack on the bruise to ease blood circulation
Myth3: \n Squeeze the stinger to treat a bee sting
Myth4: \n Tilt your head back to stop a nosebleed
Myth5: \n Treat a black eye with a ice wrapped in a clean towel

If you apply butter or an oily substance to a serious burn, you could make it difficult for a doctor to treat the burn later and increase risk of infection. The right approach: Treat a burn with cool water. If a burn is severe and starts to blister, make sure to see a doctor. Keep the affected area clean and loosely covered with a dry, sterile dressing

What to do: The best home treatment is to apply an ice pack on the bruise; this will reduce the internal bleeding. The ice should not touch the skin directly since this can cause ice burn, similar to sunburn.

Fact: Squeezing the stinger will cause more toxins to flow into the bloodstream. \n What to do: Quickly pull out the stinger with a pair of tweezers, then apply an antihistamine cream to the affected area.

Fact: If you tilt your head back when you have a nosebleed, the blood may go into your throat and your stomach, which may lead to nausea and vomiting. \n What to do: Tilt your head forward and press the fleshy part of your nose, the part you would hold for a bad smell, for a full 10 minutes, while breathing through your mouth. If you are still bleeding after half an hour, seek emergency help.
